attributes.text:
The RepeatButton is a special button, which fires repeatedly {@link #execute} events, while the mouse button is pressed on the button. The initial delay and the interval time can be set using the properties {@link #firstInterval} and {@link #interval}. The {@link #execute} events will be fired in a shorter amount of time if the mouse button is hold, until the min {@link #minTimer} is reached. The {@link #timerDecrease} property sets the amount of milliseconds which will decreased after every firing.

  var button = new qx.ui.form.RepeatButton("Hello World");

  button.addListener("execute", function(e) {
    alert("Button is executed");
  }, this);

  this.getRoot.add(button);

This example creates a button with the label “Hello World” and attaches an event listener to the {@link #execute} event.

External Documentation

Documentation of this widget in the qooxdoo wiki.
Label to use
Icon to use
This event gets dispatched with every interval. The timer gets executed as long as the user holds down the mouse button.
This event gets dispatched when the button is pressed.
This event gets dispatched when the button is released.
Starts the internal timer which causes firing of execution events in an interval. It also presses the button.
Stops the internal timer and releases the button.
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the property enabled.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #enabled}.
interval event

Callback for the interval event.

Stops the timer and starts it with a new interval (value of the “interval” property – value of the “timerDecrease” property). Dispatches the “execute” event.
Key event

Listener method for “keydown” event.

Removes “abandoned” and adds “pressed” state for the keys “Enter” or “Space”. It also starts the internal timer (same like mousedown).
Key event

Listener method for “keyup” event.

Removes “abandoned” and “pressed” state (if “pressed” state is set) for the keys “Enter” or “Space” and stopps the internal timer (same like mouse up).
mouseDown event

Callback method for the “mouseDown” method.

Sets the interval of the timer (value of firstInterval property) and starts the timer. Additionally removes the state “abandoned” and adds the state “pressed”.
Mouse event

Listener method for “mouseout” event

  • Removes “hovered” state
  • Adds “abandoned” and removes “pressed” state (if “pressed” state is set)
Mouse event

Listener method for “mouseover” event

  • Adds state “hovered”
  • Removes “abandoned” and adds “pressed” state (if “abandoned” state is set)
mouseUp event

Callback method for the “mouseUp” event.

Handles the case that the user is releasing the mouse button before the timer interval method got executed. This way the “execute” method get executed at least one time.

Returns the (computed) value of the property firstInterval.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #firstInterval}.
(Computed) value of firstInterval.

Returns the (computed) value of the property interval.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #interval}.
(Computed) value of interval.

Returns the (computed) value of the property minTimer.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #minTimer}.
(Computed) value of minTimer.

Returns the (computed) value of the property timerDecrease.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #timerDecrease}.
(Computed) value of timerDecrease.
Initial value for property firstInterval.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property firstInterval with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #firstInterval}.
the default value
Initial value for property interval.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property interval with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #interval}.
the default value
Initial value for property minTimer.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property minTimer with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #minTimer}.
the default value
Initial value for property timerDecrease.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property timerDecrease with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #timerDecrease}.
the default value
Calling this function is like a click from the user on the button with all consequences. Be sure to call the {@link #release} function.
flag which signals, if a event should be fired
Calling this function is like a release from the user on the button with all consequences. Usually the {@link #release} function will be called before the call of this function.

Resets the user value of the property firstInterval.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #firstInterval}.

Resets the user value of the property interval.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #interval}.

Resets the user value of the property minTimer.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #minTimer}.

Resets the user value of the property timerDecrease.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #timerDecrease}.
New value for property firstInterval.

Sets the user value of the property firstInterval.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #firstInterval}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property interval.

Sets the user value of the property interval.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #interval}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property minTimer.

Sets the user value of the property minTimer.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #minTimer}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property timerDecrease.

Sets the user value of the property timerDecrease.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #timerDecrease}.
The unmodified incoming value.
Interval used for the first run of the timer. Usually a greater value than the “interval” property value to a little delayed reaction at the first time.
Interval used after the first run of the timer. Usually a smaller value than the “firstInterval” property value to get a faster reaction.
This configures the minimum value for the timer interval.
Decrease of the timer on each interval (for the next interval) until minTimer reached.
